G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers to fashion appropriate parenting-time conditions, including supervised parenting time, restrictions on overnights, and other safeguards to protect the child’s safety and welfare. See Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981); Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 712 (1979); G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time judgment where there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment and where modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; see also Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard for determining custody (best interests of the child) and affirms the judge’s discretionary custody decision, but it does not address modification of a prior custody or parenting-time judgment based on a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The case involves an initial custody determination in connection with dissolution of a relationship, not a postjudgment modification proceeding. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’” (Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. at 494).

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time judgment where there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment and where modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; see also Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 209C in a relocation/paternity context, not on the standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting-time judgment. It does not discuss G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor articulate the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ plus ‘best interests of the child’ test for modification. While it references best interests and stability generally, it does not establish or affirm the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.... Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child."

Custody of Kale, 409 Mass. 844, 848 (199.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the “paramount concern” in custody and parenting-time matters is the best interests of the child. See Custody of Kale, 409 Mass. 844, 848 (1991); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998).
Custody of Kale, 409 Mass. 844, 848 (199.case_name: Murphy v. LS.K.Con. of New England, Inc.
Custody of Kale, 409 Mass. 844, 848 (199.support_reasoning: This opinion is not Custody of Kale at all; it is a tort and First Amendment case involving ISKCON (the Hare Krishna temple) and Susan and Mary Murphy. It does not address custody, parenting time, or the best interests of the child standard. Accordingly, this text does not support the proposition about Massachusetts custody law or the ‘paramount concern’ being the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kale, 409 Mass. 844, 848 (199.relevant_excerpt: The provided opinion concerns tort claims (intentional infliction of emotional distress, interference with parental rights, breach of duty of care, vicarious liability) and First Amendment free exercise issues arising from Susan Murphy’s involvement with ISKCON N.E.; it contains no discussion of child custody standards or ‘best interests of the child.’

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the “paramount concern” in custody and parenting-time matters is the best interests of the child. See Custody of Kale, 409 Mass. 844, 848 (1991); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody standards and repeatedly references the child’s welfare and the impact of domestic violence, but it does not contain a clear statement that the ‘paramount concern’ in custody and parenting-time matters is the best interests of the child. The quoted sections focus on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and statutory requirements, rather than articulating or reaffirming the general best-interests standard as the controlling or ‘paramount’ principle. Thus, it does not directly support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ ... ‘Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.’

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the “paramount concern” in custody and parenting-time matters is the best interests of the child. See Custody of Kale, 409 Mass. 844, 848 (1991); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the dispositive issue in terms of the child’s best interests and applies that standard as the controlling consideration in choosing between competing adoptive placements. While it does not use the exact phrase “paramount concern,” it clearly identifies the best interests of the child as the central, governing standard in custody/adoption determinations under G. L. c. 210, § 3, consistent with the proposition cited alongside Kale and Vaughn.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Presented with more than one potential adoption placement, the judge’s task is to determine which plan will serve the best interests of the child…”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: To justify modification, the moving party must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior order, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981); Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for making an initial custody determination in a divorce judgment and emphasizes that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and best interests. It does not address modification of an existing custody or support order, nor does it discuss any requirement of showing a material and substantial change in circumstances. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the two-prong modification standard stated in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). … This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: To justify modification, the moving party must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the prior order, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981); Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996).
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets G.L. c. 208, § 28 as requiring, for modification of a prior custody judgment, both (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that the modification be necessary in the children’s best interests. The court then applies this two-part framework, first upholding the finding of a material and substantial change and next reviewing whether the new custody arrangement was in the children’s best interests. This aligns directly with the proposition for which Ardizoni is being cited.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers to fashion appropriate parenting-time conditions, including supervised parenting time, restrictions on overnights, and other safeguards to protect the child’s safety and welfare. See Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981); Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 712 (1979); G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: Felton concerns modification of visitation to restrict a noncustodial parent’s religious instruction and focuses on the constitutional and evidentiary limits on restricting a parent’s religious activities. The court reverses a restrictive condition because there was insufficient proof of harm, and while it acknowledges that visitation can be ‘limited materially or cancelled’ if properly supported, it does not discuss or endorse broad equitable power to craft specific parenting-time conditions like supervised visits or overnight restrictions. The case is about when religious-based restrictions are impermissible, not an affirmative articulation of broad supervisory or safeguarding powers over parenting time.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “The decisions hold such an infirmity to be fatal to an action seeking to limit materially or to cancel visitation rights.… The few cases which, though faithful to the accepted legal pattern earlier described, limit visitation because of religious differences, have relied on firmer proof…. It is often said that if accommodation appears necessary, that form should be sought which intrudes least on the religious inclinations of either parent and is yet compatible with the health of the child.”

Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 712 (1979).proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers to fashion appropriate parenting-time conditions, including supervised parenting time, restrictions on overnights, and other safeguards to protect the child’s safety and welfare. See Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981); Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 712 (1979); G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10.
Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 712 (1979).support_reasoning: This decision concerns care-and-protection proceedings under G.L. c. 119 and the standard for removing custody from a parent based on parental unfitness. It discusses the State’s preventive interest, the need for specific findings, and evidentiary standards, but it does not address parenting-time conditions such as supervised visitation, restrictions on overnights, or the fashioning of specific contact/visitation safeguards. Nor does it describe or rely on any broad equitable power to craft such parenting-time arrangements, so it does not substantively support the proposition cited.
Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 712 (1979).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 119, § 24...provides that any person concerned for a child’s welfare may file a petition... If the court finds that the allegations have been proved and that the child is therefore in need of “care and protection,” it may enter any order conducive to the child’s best interests, including but not limited to permanently committing the child to the Department of Public Welfare. G. L. c. 119, § 26.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The Child is now older (age 9) and better able to verbalize his experiences, including his discomfort and observations regarding Father’s behavior and the environment at Father’s home. See generally Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840–41 (2003) (recognizing children’s evolving needs and circumstances over time as relevant to best‑interest analysis).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The cited pages in Custody of Kali focus on the historical development and content of the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, the statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and especially the importance of stability and continuity with a primary caregiver. The opinion does not discuss a child’s age‑related ability to verbalize experiences, discomfort, or observations about a parent’s behavior or home environment. Thus, using this case as authority for children’s evolving capacity to express their experiences as part of the best‑interest analysis overstates what the decision actually holds.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.” (Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 843).

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.raw_text: Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704, 711–13 (1984)
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that evidence of substance abuse or impaired parenting abilities may warrant modification of custody or parenting time to protect a child’s welfare. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704, 711–13 (1984); Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886–87 (1997).
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The case concerns a care-and-protection proceeding focused on parental unfitness, instability, and neglect (inadequate housing, leaving children with inappropriate caretakers, inconsistent visitation, refusal of counseling), not substance abuse or specifically ‘impaired parenting abilities’ in the sense used in the proposition. Although the opinion briefly notes the mother’s refusal to attend alcohol or drug counseling in a footnote, the court does not rely on substance abuse evidence or frame its holding around substance abuse as a basis for modifying custody or parenting time. Thus it does not meaningfully support the proposition that Massachusetts courts have recognized substance abuse as a ground for modifying custody or parenting time.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s findings are adequate under this standard to support the removal of the children from the mother’s care. He found that she was a ‘disorganized, immature, irresponsible, inconsistent person whose inadequacies as a parent have deprived her children of the basic physical needs of food, clothing, shelter and basic emotional needs.’ … Although the record indicates that the mother has considerable love for her children and they for her, it also demonstrates a lack of consistency and responsibility on her part.”

Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886\.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that evidence of substance abuse or impaired parenting abilities may warrant modification of custody or parenting time to protect a child’s welfare. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704, 711–13 (1984); Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886–87 (1997).
Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886\.support_reasoning: Adoption of Quentin is a termination-of-parental-rights/adoption case focused on parental unfitness, not on modification of custody or parenting time based specifically on substance abuse or impaired parenting in an ongoing custody regime. While the court notes, among many factors, that the father used public assistance to purchase drugs and that the mother lacked capacity to care for the children, it does so in the context of dispensing with consent to adoption, not modifying existing custody or visitation arrangements. The case therefore does not squarely support the narrower proposition about modification of custody or parenting time due to substance abuse or impaired parenting abilities.
Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 886\.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that there was adequate evidence to support the findings that: the parents maintained an unsafe and unsanitary home and failed to take steps to correct these conditions; the parents lived an itinerant lifestyle which was harmful to the children; they neglected the emotional well-being of the children; the father never displayed a long-term commitment to stay with the family; the father used the public assistance funds to purchase drugs; the mother lacked the ability to protect the children from the father’s harmful conduct; and the mother lacked the capacity to deal with the needs of the children. Taken together, these facts provide clear and convincing evidence that both parents were unfit.
